title: On the material and the symbolic: Silverstone’s double articulation of research traditions in new media studies

references.title: (2006b) Media and Morality: On the rise of the mediapolis.
references.raw: Silverstone, R. (2006b) Media and Morality: On the rise of the mediapolis. Cambridge: Polity.

references.title: 5 Dr Who is a hugely popular science fiction drama series, produced off and on by the BBC since the 1960s and sold worldwide (Fiske,
references.raw: 5 Dr Who is a hugely popular science fiction drama series, produced off and on by the BBC since the 1960s and sold worldwide (Fiske, 1984).

references.title: 6 Though the importance of symbolic interpretation is already lost in the inadequate term, ‘user’; Lievrouw and Livingstone
references.raw: 6 Though the importance of symbolic interpretation is already lost in the inadequate term, ‘user’; Lievrouw and Livingstone (2006). The interpretative is best captured, in my view, by the analogy of ‘the reader’ – of texts, of the world; hence the notion of literacy may prove most fruitful in the long term. 7 A major UK weekly magazine listing the television schedules.

references.title: Audiences: A Sociological Theory of Performance and Imagination.
references.raw: Abercrombie, N., & Longhurst, B. (1998). Audiences: A Sociological Theory of Performance and Imagination. London: Sage.

references.title: Complicity and collusion in the mediation of everyday life.
references.raw: Silverstone, R. (2002). Complicity and collusion in the mediation of everyday life. New Literary History, 33, 761-780.

references.title: Consuming Technologies: Media and Information in Domestic Spaces.
references.raw: Silverstone, R., & Hirsch, E. (Eds.). (1992). Consuming Technologies: Media and Information in Domestic Spaces. London: Routledge.

references.title: Differences in actual and perceived online skills: The role of gender.
references.raw: Hargittai, E., & Shafer, S. (2006). Differences in actual and perceived online skills: The role of gender. Social Science Quarterly, 87(2), 432-448.

references.raw: Silverstone, R. (2006a). Domesticating domestication: Reflections on the life of a7 concept. In T. Berker, M. Hartmann, Y. Punie & K. J. Ward (Eds.), The domestication of media and technology (pp. 229-248). Maidenhead: Open University Press.

references.raw: Silverstone, R., Morley, D., Dahlberg, A., and Livingstone, S. (1989) Families, technologies and consumption: The household and information and communication technologies. CRICT Discussion Paper, Brunel University.

references.title: for example, Spigel
references.raw: 2 See, for example, Spigel (1992) and Putnam and Newton (1990).

Popularity and ideology: A structuralist reading of DR. WHO. In W. D. Rowland & B. Watkins (Eds.), Interpreting Television: Current Research Perspectives (pp. 58-73). Beverly Hills, Cal.: Sage.
